titleStmt.title: Effects of environmental dilution on body fluid regulation in the yellow stingray, Urolophus jamaicensis

analytic.title: Effects of environmental dilution on body fluid regulation in the yellow stingray, Urolophus jamaicensis

biblStruct.note: Received 7 March 2000; received in revised form 5 September 2000; accepted 4 October 2000

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Ž. Adult yellow stingrays Urolophus jamaicensis , collected off the southeast Florida coast, were maintained in filtered Ž. and re-circulated synthetic sea water 33‰ for 5᎐13 days at 30ЊC. Animals exposed to 82%, 74% and 66% SW in gradual steps exhibited rapid and significant weight gains followed by recovery to pre-dilution levels in 2᎐6 days. w Ž. Ž. Ž. Ž .x Ž. Acclimated animals at each salinity 100% N s 12 , 82% 7 , 74% 4 and 66% SW 3 were anesthetized MS222 and bled from the caudal vein. In 100% SW, stingray plasma was slightly hypo-osmotic to the external medium. Plasma w x osmolality decreased with stepwise dilutions, but became increasingly hyperosmotic to the bathing media. Plasma Na w x w x and Cl each decreased by approximately 13%, 23% and 16%, respectively, in 82%, 74% and 66% SW. Plasma urea w x w x w x decreased by 21%, 25% and 59%, respectively. Changes in plasma K and Ca were minor. Mean corpuscular Hb measurements suggest that stingray red cells swelled less at each dilution than predicted for a passive erythrocyte w x osmometer. RBC K decreased by 12%, 36% and 29%, respectively, in 82%, 74% and 66% SW. Quantitatively, the Ž. other measured electrolytes Cl, Na and Ca changed by lesser amounts. Results suggest that for mild and moderate Ž. dilutions 82% and 74% SW , yellow stingrays release both ions and urea from intracellular and extracellular Ž. compartments. With further dilution 66% SW , the elasmobranchs retain electrolytes at the expense of urea.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The effects of environmental perturbations on body fluid homeostasis have been investigated to U Corresponding author. Tel.: q1-603-862-4153; fax: q1-603-862-3784.

Ž . E-mail address: jsulikow@hotmail.com J.A. Sulikowski . 1 Current address: Zoology Department, University of New Hampshire, Durham, NH 03824, USA. a lesser degree among elasmobranchs than for Ž most other vertebrate classes Pang et al., 1977;. Shuttleworth, 1988;Karnaky, 1998 . Research on a limited number of marine elasmobranchs has shown that the extracellular fluids are generally maintained slightly hyperosmotic to the surround-Ž ing medium Smith, 1929;Holmes and Donald-. son, 1969;Shuttleworth, 1988 . This condition is achieved by regulating the concentrations of sodium and chloride at about half those present ( ) in sea water, while maintaining elevated levels of Ž . Ž urea and trimethylamine oxide TMAO Smith, 1929;Holmes and Donaldson, 1969;Shuttle-. worth, 1988 . While sharks and rays are predominately marine, many elasmobranch species possess the osmoregulatory capacity for tolerating moderate to substantial reductions in environmental salinity Ž . Thorson, 1967;De Vlaming and Sage, 1973 . Laboratory investigations have shown significant reductions in plasma osmolality following the acclimation of elasmobranchs to diluted sea water Ž environments Price and Creaser, 1967;Price, 1967;Goldstein et al., 1968;Goldstein and Forster, 1971;De Vlaming and Sage, 1973;Forster and Goldstein, 1976;Chan and Wong, 1977; . Cooper and Morris, 1998 . Furthermore, several of these studies reported disproportionate changes in the concentrations of plasma electrolytes and nitrogenous compounds, suggesting individual regulation of the extracellular solutes associated with environmental dilution. Unfortunately, few of these dilution investigations considered the corresponding responses of the intracellular com-Ž partment Forster and Goldstein, 1976;Chan and . Wong, 1977;Cooper and Morris, 1998 . Ž . The yellow stingray Urolophus jamaicensis , a marine elasmobranch, routinely inhabits waters that undergo moderate salinity fluctuations Ž . Yanez- Arancibia, 1979 . The objectives of the present investigation were to determine the effects of stepwise environmental dilution on body fluid regulation in U. jamaicensis. More specifically, this study sought to characterize the water and solute composition for plasma and a single Ž . intracellular compartment erythrocytes as a function of environmental salinity. Our hypothesis was that the ionic osmolytes of both fluid compartments would be conserved at the expense of urea as external salinity decreased.

div.head: Ž
div.p: . Adult yellow stingrays Urolophus jamaicensis were captured by divers using hand nets from the coastal waters off John U. Lloyd State Park, Da-Ž . nia, Florida. Prior to shipment to Chicago IL , the animals were maintained in sheltered fiber glass aquaria supplied with a constant flow of fresh sea water at ambient temperature at the Nova Southeastern University Oceanographic Ž . Center. Thirteen de-barbed stingrays 168᎐619 g were packaged in waterproof containers filled with Ž . oxygenated 100% O sea water and transported 2 to DePaul University by air courier.

In the laboratory, animals were housed in three Ž . glass tanks 151 and 208 l supplied with aerated, re-circulating synthetic sea water. Water quality was maintained by continuous re-circulation through an external biological and mechanical Ž . filtration system. The salinity 33‰ and temper-Ž . ature 30ЊC of the laboratory water were similar to those of the stingrays' natural environment. The elasmobranchs were fed frozen shrimp during initial captivity in Florida; in the laboratory at DePaul University, the stingrays were maintained in an unfed state. All animals were assumed to be sexually mature based on the morphometric crite-Ž . ria of Martin and Cailliet 1988 .

div.head: Sea water dilution protocol
div.p: Stingrays were maintained in 100% sea water Ž . control conditions for 5᎐13 days prior to experimental dilution. Statistical analyses revealed no differences in experimental data among animals Ž acclimated for 5 and 13 days in 100% SW t-test;

. P) 0.05 . Upon acclimation, animals were exposed to 82%, 74% and 66% sea water in a gradual stepwise manner, similar to the protocol Ž . of Goldstein et al. 1968 andŽ . Forster 1971 . For each dilution, dechlorinated fresh water was gradually added to the aquarium medium until the specified salinity was achieved Ž . approx. 30 min . Stingrays were acclimated at each salinity level before the next dilution was initiated. Acclimation to sea water dilutions was judged by body weight stabilization. Body masses were recorded on the first and second days postdilution and every other day thereafter.

div.head: Blood collection
div.formula: w Ž Upon acclimation to each salinity 100% N s . Ž . Ž . Ž .
div.p: x 12 , 82% 7 , 74% 4 , and 66% 3 SW , individual stingrays were anesthetized with 3-amino-Ž benzoic acid ethyl ester MS222; Sigma Chemical . Co.; 0.05 grl in 3 l of their external medium. Ž . Once anesthetized approx. 5 min , blood samples Ž . 450᎐990 l were collected from the caudal vein into chilled, heparinized syringes with a 26-gauge ( ) needle and placed on ice. Determinations of blood hematocrit, plasma and whole blood water content, and plasma osmolality commenced immediately. Samples of plasma, erythrocytes and external media were prepared and stored for later analyses of solute concentrations as described below.

div.head: Plasma and erythrocyte water contents
div.p: Duplicate 50 l samples of separated plasma and whole blood, dispensed into aluminum pans with a Hamilton syringe, were weighed on a Ž . semi-micro balance Sartorious model 2400 be-Ž . fore and after oven drying 24᎐26 h at 90ЊC . The specific gravity and water content for plasma and whole blood were measured directly; the corresponding erythrocyte values were calculated from the plasma and whole blood data and the Hct. The RBC water content values were corrected for Ž an assumed 4% trapped plasma volume Semple . et al., 1970 .

div.head: Inorganic electrolytes
div.p: Plasma and separated erythrocytes were prepared for electrolyte determinations by methods similar to those described by Maginniss and Hitzig Ž . 1987 . Briefly, the separated red cells were rapidly Ž . washed twice with 2 volumes of cold isosmotic Ž mannitol, centrifuged for 2 min at 9400 = g IEC . Micromax and the supernatant aspirated. The packed RBCs were treated with 2 volumes of cold Ž . 9% trichloracetic acid TCA and placed on ice with frequent vortex mixing to facilitate hemoly-Ž sis. The samples were then centrifuged 2 min at . Ž . 9400 = g and the supernatant stored y70ЊC for later analysis. The separated plasma was treated with 1 volume of cold 12% TCA, centrifuged and the supernatant stored at y70ЊC. External media samples were stored untreated at y70ЊC.

Plasma and RBC concentrations of sodium, potassium and calcium were determined by flame Ž .w x photometry Bacharach model 51Ca ; Cl was Ž . measured by chloride titration HaakeBuchler . Standards were prepared to eliminate or to correct for potential interference caused by TCA andror blood electrolytes. Ion concentrations are Ž . presented as mmolerl plasma or RBC water.

div.head: Plasma urea
div.p: Separated plasma was treated with 1 volume of cold 12% TCA, centrifuged and the supernatant Ž . stored y70ЊC for later urea analysis. Plasma w
x Ž . urea mmolerl plasma H O was determined 2 Ž . spectrophotometrically 535 nm as urea nitrogen Ž . Sigma Chemical Co., Tech. Bull. 535A .

div.head: Statistical data analysis
div.p: The results are presented as mean " 1 S.E.M. Ž . N . Statistical comparisons of between-group data were performed using a repeated measure of analysis of variance for means of independent samples. A Bonferroni post-hoc test was implemented to further assess statistical significance, which was accepted at P-0.05.

div.head: Effects of en¨ironmental dilution on body mass
div.p: Stingrays maintained in 100% SW and in a non-feeding state lost 0.77" 0.12% of their body weight per day. Environmental dilution, however, elicited substantial increases in body mass within Ž . 24 h of exposure Table 1 . Since the stingrays were not fed during the dilution experiments, the observed weight changes must be attributed to increased water uptake. Animal body weights returned to near pre-dilution levels within 2᎐6 days of initial exposure, suggesting the regulation of Ž . body fluid volume Table 1 . Fig. 1 illustrates the time course of weight change for stingrays transferred from 100% to 82% SW. As the dilution ( ) series progressed, acclimation times were reduced Že.g. stingrays transferred to 82% SW achieved body weight stabilization in approximately 6 days, while the average acclimation period in 66% SW . was 2 days .

div.head: Plasma osmolality
div.p: The blood plasma of control yellow stingrays Ž . 100% SW was slightly hypo-osmotic to the ex-Ž . ternal medium Fig. 2 . Acclimation to each of Ž the experimental dilutions 82%, 74% and 66%
. SW caused significant decreases in plasma os-Ž . molality t-test, P-0.05 . However, with each dilution, the animals' plasma became increasingly Ž hyperosmotic to the external environment Fig. . 2 .

div.head: Blood water content and hematologic properties
div.p: Experimental dilution had no effect on plasma Ž . water content Table 2 ; values for the four salinity groups ranged from 96.6% to 97.5% H O.
RBC water content for rays acclimated to 74% and 66% SW was significantly greater than for the controls, suggestive of erythrocyte swelling Ž . Table 2 .

w x Experimental dilution had no effect on Hb Ž . Table 2 . Hct exhibited an increasing trend with dilution, but no values were significantly different w x from control. However, the Hb rHct ratio revealed progressive and significant decreases in w x Ž . mean corpuscular Hb MCHC with experimen-Ž . tal dilution Table 2 . These latter findings are consistent with dilution-induced RBC swelling.

div.head: Plasma and erythrocyte solutes
div.p: Sodium and chloride, the two major plasma electrolytes, decreased by approximately 13%, 23% and 16%, respectively, in 82%, 74% and Ž . w x w x 66% SW Table 3 . Plasma K and Ca for stingrays in 66% SW were significantly different from control values. However, absolute changes in these latter two electrolytes were quantitatively Ž . minor for all experimental dilutions Table 3 . Urea, which represented approximately 38% of the measured plasma solutes in control animals, decreased by 21%, 25% and 59%, respectively, in 82%, 74% and 66% SW.

Potassium, the major RBC cation, decreased by 12%, 36% and 29%, respectively, in 82%, 74% Ž . w x w x and 66% SW Table 4 . Erythrocyte Na and Ca exhibited small but significant decreases in 74% and 66% SW. Chloride, the major RBC anion measured, revealed no significant changes with environmental dilution. Because of the anticipated efflux of urea from the stingray RBC during the mannitol wash procedure, erythrocyte urea Ž concentrations have not been reported discussed . further below .

div.head: Methodology: transmembrane urea distribution and¨alidation of intracellular electrolyte determinations
div.p: The absence of urea determinations for U. jamaicensis red cells represents a potential limita- Forster and Goldstein, 1976;Walsh et al., 1994;Cooper and Morris, 1998; . Sulikowski and Howell, unpublished . Furthermore, several of these investigations reported equivalent transmembrane urea concentrations for elasmobranchs acclimated to 50% SW as well as 100% SW. The literature also provides strong evidence for simple diffusion as the primary or sole mechanism of urea transport across elas-Ž mobranch RBC membranes Rabinowitz and Gunther, 1973;Kaplan et al., 1974;Walsh et al., . 1994;Carlson and Goldstein, 1997 . Moreover, Ž . Carlson and Goldstein 1997 identified the specific avenue for urea exchange in the little skate erythrocyte as the lipid membrane rather than aqueous channelsrpores. Given sufficient time andror membrane permeability, passive diffusion would dissipate transient urea gradients. There is increasing evidence that membrane permeability to urea may be lower than previously thought Ž . Walsh et al., 1994;Carlson and Goldstein, 1997 . However, the measured or estimated rates of urea transport across elasmobranch red cells appear sufficient for the rapid equalization of this organic solute following osmotic perturbations ŽRabinowitz and Gunther, 1973;Kaplan et al., 1974;Walsh et al., 1994;Carlson and Goldstein, . 1997 .

During the preparation phase for RBC solute determinations, separated erythrocytes were freed of adhering plasma solutes by two rapid washes with equivalent volumes of isosmotic mannitol. Because of the membrane's permeability to urea, Ž . the organic solute with H O following undoubt-2 edly effluxed into the mannitol wash. Consew x quently, the measured RBC urea underestimated the true intracellular quantity. However, assuming that urea was uniformly distributed Ž . across the RBC membrane as discussed above for each of the four salinity conditions and that the urea efflux into the mannitol wash was accompanied by a corresponding H O volume, then

div.head: Volume regulation: whole body
div.p: Like many other marine elasmobranchs, the yellow stingray has a demonstrated capacity for survival and acclimation in reduced salinity environments. In its natural habitat, U. jamaicensis ( ) migrates between media ranging from 100% to Ž . 81% SW Yanez-Arancibia, 1979 . In the laboratory, stingrays exhibited rapid and significant increases in body mass upon dilution exposure; average weight increases of 7᎐10% were recorded within 24 h of exposure to the three dilution steps Ž . A general criterion of osmoregulation among marine elasmobranchs that tolerate salinity dilutions is the capacity to reverse the initial water uptake and return the body weight to near pre-Ž dilution levels Goldstein and Forster, 1971;De . Vlaming and Sage, 1973 . For the yellow stingray, body fluid recovery was generally achieved within 2᎐6 days for each of the three experimental Ž . groups Table 1, Fig. 1 . These acclimation data for U. jamaicensis are within the time frame reported for efficient elasmobranch osmoregulators ŽGoldstein et al., 1968;De Vlaming and Sage, . 1973

div.head: Volume regulation: erythrocyte
div.p: The significant changes in RBC water content w x and mean corpuscular Hb with environmental Ž . dilution Table 2 are both indicative of erythrocyte swelling. These data further suggest that the stingray is capable of cell volume regulation during hypo-osmotic exposure. Fig. 3 compares the percentage change in RBC volume for a passive Ž . non-regulating erythrocyte osmometer with a cell whose volume reflects the observed changes Ž . in MCHC Table 2 for each of the dilutions. For this analysis, the RBC osmometer is assumed to be freely permeable to water, impermeable to electrolytes, and that the measured plasma osmolalities represent the extracellular conditions Ž . Fig. 2; Table 3 . The graphed relationship suggests that during hypo-osmotic exposure, the stingray erythrocytes are regulated at a volume substantially less than the passive RBC osmometer, especially for the lower salinities.

div.head: Extracellular solute regulation
div.p: Most marine elasmobranchs are slightly hyper-Ž osmotic to their sea water environment Smith, 1929;Holmes and Donaldson, 1969;Shuttle-. worth, 1988 . In contrast, plasma osmolality for the yellow stingray was slightly hypo-osmotic to the sea water medium. One possible explanation may relate to the animal's unfed state. Haywood Ž . 1973 reported significant reductions in serum Ž . Ž Fig. 3. Predicted effects of environmental dilution on RBC volume for two conditions: 1 passive erythrocyte osmometer no volume . Ž . regulation ; and 2 red cell volumes calculated from MCHC data. See text for further details.

div.head: Ž
div.p: . urea and osmolarity up to 50 mOsmrl for the Ž . unfed Pyjama shark Poroderma africanum . A second possibility suggests that the hypo-osmolality may reflect U. jamaicensis' normal osmoregulatory state in 100% SW.

Plasma osmolality decreased with hypo-osmotic exposure, but not in proportion to medium dilution, i.e. the elasmobranchs became progressively Ž . hyperosmotic with environmental dilution Fig. 2 . Comparable results have been reported for other euryhaline elasmobranchs such as the lip shark, Ž the little skate and the Atlantic stingray Goldstein and Forster, 1971;De Vlaming and Sage, . 1973;Chan and Wong, 1977 . Like the yellow stingray, these latter fish also experienced significant reductions in plasma osmolality, while maintaining increasing osmotic gradients between plasma and external media during environmental dilution. These findings suggest a common strategy of osmoregulation among euryhaline elasmobranchs.

The measured plasma solutes also exhibited significant dilution-induced changes in concentra-Ž . tion Table 3 , consistent with the corresponding osmolality values. However, the relative variations in plasma solutes were generally disproportionate; hence, regulation of the individual plasma solutes seems likely. If the observed changes in solute concentration had simply been a function of environmental dilution, then all solutes would have been altered by comparable amounts. All Ž measured plasma solutes, with one exception Ca . in 66% SW , exhibited concentration reductions for stingrays acclimated to the sea water dilutions Ž . Table 3 . Whether most elasmobranchs that migrate into dilute environments regulate their plasma solutes individually remains largely untested. However, the data presented in Table 5 suggest that this type of adjustment does occur in Ž some euryhaline species Goldstein et al., 1968;Goldstein and Forster, 1971;De Vlaming and . Sage, 1973;Chan and Wong, 1977 . The major contributors to the dilution-induced Ž . solute reductions were Na, Cl and urea Table 3 .

w x w x w x In 82% SW, plasma Na , Cl and urea were reduced 13%, 13% and 21% below control levels, respectively; in 74% SW, the corresponding values were 22%, 23% and 25%, respectively. Therefore, within the salinity range that this animal Ž normally inhabits 81᎐ 100% SW; Yanez-. Arancibia, 1979 , the yellow stingray regulates its extracellular fluid concentration in hypo-osmotic environments through comparable reductions of each of the three major plasma solutes. In the Ž . most dilute medium 66% SW , further losses of the two primary electrolytes were curtailed. In fact, plasma concentrations of Na and Cl were reduced only 17% and 15%, respectively, below control levels. The animal's lower limit of tolerance for extracellular ionic dilution may occur within this concentration range. Solute compensation for the transition from 74% to 66% SW was, therefore, achieved largely by further and substantial reductions of extracellular urea. In 66% w x SW, the plasma urea of acclimated stingrays was reduced by 59% below control levels. Similar findings have been reported for other dilutiontolerant sharks and rays. Table 5 shows that for several marine elasmobranchs acclimated in media ranging from 77% to 26% SW, the measured w x declines in plasma urea were greater, and in some cases two times greater, than those exhibw x w x ited by Na andror Cl .

w x w x The small changes in plasma K and Ca suggest that neither cation makes a quantitative contribution to extracellular osmoregulation associ-Ž . ated with environmental dilution Table 3 . These observations may reflect the significant roles played by potassium and calcium in transmembrane gradients, secondary messenger reactions, and nerve and muscle function, and thus the necessity for their tighter regulation than for other extracellular solutes.

div.head: Intracellular solute regulation
div.p: Ž The three measured RBC cations K, Na and . Ca exhibited similar responses to environmental Ž . dilution Table 4 ; however, only potassium made a significant quantitative contribution to the change in ionic concentration. The three cations were reduced by 12᎐16% in 82% SW and 32᎐37% in 74% SW, while in 66% SW, the electrolytes revealed a leveling off effect which may reflect the animal's lower limit of tolerance for intracellular ionic concentration. These trends are similar Ž . to those reported for plasma Na and Cl Table 3 . Chloride, the only measured RBC anion, was maintained at a high and constant concentration for the four salinity conditions. A similar rew x sponse in RBC Cl was exhibited by the Port Ž . Jackson shark H. portusjacksoni upon acclima-Ž . tion to 50% SW Cooper and Morris, 1998 . Ž . Robertson 1989 reported high concentrations of inorganic phosphate anion in muscle of spotted Ž . dogfish S. canicula . This latter electrolyte might serve an important role in intraerythrocytic solute regulation in U. jamaicensis. Furthermore, the increased RBC volume associated with environmental dilution reduced the effective concentra-Ž tion of impermeant polyanionic species e.g. pro-. teins and organic phosphates .

Intracellular concentrations of urea were not reported for the yellow stingray. However, the literature provides considerable support for the uniform distribution of urea across the RBC Ž . membrane of elasmobranchs see Section 4.1 . w x We suggest, therefore, that the urea for erythrocytes and plasma in U. jamaicensis were nearly identical and exhibited comparable declines with Ž . Ž environmental dilution Table 3 , Walsh et al., . 1994;Carlson and Goldstein, 1997 . We further w x predict that the stingray RBC urea experienced a substantial reduction associated with the 74% to 66% SW transition, while the measured electrolytes remained largely unchanged.

We conclude that when exposed to mild or Ž . moderate dilutions 82% and 74% SW , yellow stingrays regulated their body fluid compartments slightly hyperosmotic to the external milieu by comparable reductions of the major electrolytes Ž . and urea. With greater dilution 66% SW , these elasmobranchs maintained their hyperosmotic state by eliminating additional urea, while resisting further reductions of electrolytes. The evolutionary strategy for this may be related to the energetics of osmoregulation. With substantial environmental dilution, the metabolic costs of ultimately replacing lost urea may be off-set by the reductions in solute gradients between the plasma and external medium for the electrolytes as well as urea.

Ž . concentrations of the plasma and corresponding bathing medium were significantly different t-test; P -0.05 . Error bars "1 S.E.M. Ž . Ž for plasma data fell within the area of the plotted symbol. The asterisk indicates significant difference P -0.05 from control 100% . SW .

it was possible to quantify the intracellular electrolytes in units of mmolerl RBC H O. These 2 latter determinations required measurements of blood sample and TCA volumes, Hct, RBC H O w x content, plasma and erythrocyte urea , and an Ž . estimate of trapped plasma volume 4% .

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: We thank Dr Richard Spieler and his graduate students at Nova Southeastern University Oceanographic Center for the use of lab materials, animal holding facilities, equipment and help in collection of the stingrays in South Florida. Thanks are further extended to Dr Frederick Prete for assisting with statistical analysis of the data and to Mark Gonka for his expertise with salt water aquaria and animal maintenance at DePaul University. This project was supported, in part, by LA& S and URC grants from DePaul University.
